title: On Finding Small Hyper-Gradients in Bilevel Optimization: Hardness Results and Improved Analysis

sections.the assumptions for nonconvex-pl bilevel:
Without the typical lower-level strong convexity assumption, it is difficult to directly analyze the implicit gradient as EquationÂ 4 since we can not directly use the implicit function theorem. Recently, Kwon etÂ al.  proposed a novel way to study the differentiability of Ï†â€‹(x)ğœ‘ğ‘¥\varphi(x) for nonconvex-PL bilevel problems. if taking minimum in yğ‘¦y over all the domain yâˆˆâ„2ğ‘¦superscriptâ„2y\in{\mathbb{R}}^{2}, Ï†Ïƒâ€‹(x)subscriptğœ‘ğœğ‘¥\varphi_{\sigma}(x) is not well-defined since Ï†Ïƒâ€‹(x)=âˆ’âˆsubscriptğœ‘ğœğ‘¥\varphi_{\sigma}(x)=-\infty for any xâ‰ 0ğ‘¥0x\neq 0; if taking minimum in yğ‘¦y over a compact domain such as ğ’´=[ref]0 Ã—[ref]0 ğ’´0101{\mathcal{Y}}=[ref]0 \times[ref]0 , Ï†Ïƒâ€‹(x)=minâ¡{x,0}subscriptğœ‘ğœğ‘¥ğ‘¥0\varphi_{\sigma}(x)=\min\{x,0\} is not differentiable at the point x=0ğ‘¥0x=0. To guarantee the differentiability of Ï†Ïƒâ€‹(x)subscriptğœ‘ğœğ‘¥\varphi_{\sigma}(x), Kwon etÂ al.  assumed the PL condition not only holds for gğ‘”g, but also holds for the penalty function hÏƒ=Ïƒâ€‹f+gsubscriptâ„ğœğœğ‘“ğ‘”h_{\sigma}=\sigma f+g uniformly for all Ïƒğœ\sigma near zero. In addition to this assumption, the authors also imposed other standard smoothness assumptions which are typically required in previous works. These assumptions, as stated in Kwon etÂ al. , are formally presented below. Recall the bilevel problem defined inÂ EquationÂ 1, where fğ‘“f is the upper-level problem, gğ‘”g is the lower-level problem. Let hÏƒ=Ïƒâ€‹f+gsubscriptâ„ğœğœğ‘“ğ‘”h_{\sigma}=\sigma f+g be the penalty function. Suppose that The penalty function hÏƒâ€‹(x,y)subscriptâ„ğœğ‘¥ğ‘¦h_{\sigma}(x,y) is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-PL in yğ‘¦y for any 0â‰¤Ïƒâ‰¤ÏƒÂ¯0ğœÂ¯ğœ0\leq\sigma\leq\overline{\sigma}; The upper-level function fâ€‹(x,y)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦f(x,y) is Cfsubscriptğ¶ğ‘“C_{f}-Lipschitz in yğ‘¦y and has Lfsubscriptğ¿ğ‘“L_{f}-Lipschitz gradients; The lower-level function gâ€‹(x,y)ğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ‘¦g(x,y) has Lgsubscriptğ¿ğ‘”L_{g}-Lipschitz gradients; The upper-level function fâ€‹(x,y)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦f(x,y) has ÏfsubscriptğœŒğ‘“\rho_{f}-Lipschitz Hessians; The lower-level function gâ€‹(x,y)ğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ‘¦g(x,y) has ÏgsubscriptğœŒğ‘”\rho_{g}-Lipschitz Hessians. Under this assumption, we define the largest smoothness constant â„“=maxâ¡{Cf,Lf,Lg,Ïg}â„“subscriptğ¶ğ‘“subscriptğ¿ğ‘“subscriptğ¿ğ‘”subscriptğœŒğ‘”\ell=\max\{C_{f},L_{f},L_{g},\rho_{g}\} and the condition number Îº:=â„“/Î¼assignğœ…â„“ğœ‡\kappa:=\ell/\mu. Note that all the assumptions are the same as Kwon etÂ al. , except (a) may seem different from the Prox-EB assumption (Assumption 1 in Kwon etÂ al. ). However, in Appendix D we show these two assumptions can imply each other. Our narrative uses the PL condition and is therefore more convenient. As a by-product, we show the proximal operator in Kwon etÂ al.  is unnecessary, and the original F2BAÂ [ref]8 can also converge under PL conditions. Because we focus on the behavior when Ïƒğœ\sigma is close to zero, whenever we mention Ïƒğœ\sigma in the context, we always assume that Ïƒâˆˆ[0,ÏƒÂ¯]ğœ0Â¯ğœ\sigma\in[0,\overline{\sigma}] even when this condition is not explicitly stated. AssumptionÂ 4.1 ensures that the solution set Yâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŒY^{*} is stable under perturbations of Ïƒğœ\sigma and xğ‘¥x.
